docs.title: EO-Toolkit Documentation
docs.text: EO-Toolkit is a comprehensive web-based GIS platform that brings together Earth Observation (EO) data, AI-powered analytics, and interactive mapping to support development projects. It empowers users with the tools, data, and insights needed to make informed, location-specific decisions across agriculture, water, climate resilience, and infrastructure planning. https://etoolkit.terrawatch.net/

docs.title: EO Toolkit serves as:
docs.text:
• A Web-based GIS platform showcasing the application of EO technologies across multiple sectors in IsDB projects.
  • A knowledge hub summarizing past and ongoing EO-based initiatives in agriculture, water management, climate resilience, and infrastructure development.
  • A resource center offering EO datasets, methodologies, case studies, learning materials, tools, SOPs, and best practices to facilitate the integration of Earth Observation across various stages of the IsDB project lifecycle.

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
• Getting Started: Installation and setup instructions
  • User Guide: Comprehensive guide for end users
  • Features: Detailed feature documentation
  • API Reference: API endpoints and usage
  • Administration: Admin panel and management guides
  • Deployment: Production deployment instructions
  • Troubleshooting: Common issues and solutions

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
EO-Toolkit is designed for:

  • Development Organizations: Planning and monitoring development projects
  • Researchers: Conducting geospatial analysis and research
  • Policy Makers: Making data-driven decisions based on Earth Observation data
  • Agricultural Planners: Analyzing crop patterns, irrigation, and water resources
  • Climate Analysts: Studying climate trends and projections
  • Infrastructure Planners: Planning infrastructure projects with spatial context

Last Updated: February 16, 2026

docs.title: Admin Panel Guide
docs.text: The Django Admin Panel provides administrative control over EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Accessing Admin Panel
docs.text:
1. Navigate to /admin/

  3. Access admin dashboard

docs.title: Users
docs.text:
Manage user accounts:

  • Custom Users: View and manage users
  • Groups: User groups and permissions
  • Permissions: User permissions

Actions: - Create/edit users - Activate/deactivate accounts - Reset passwords - Manage permissions

docs.title: Areas
docs.text:
Manage user areas:

docs.title: Geo Data Uploads

docs.title: Task History

docs.title: Adding GeoServer Data
docs.text:
1. Go to Geo Data Uploads

  3. Fill in required fields

  5. Upload thumbnail

1. Prepare data files and JSON metadata

  3. Place JSON at /staticData/geoserver_data.json

docs.title: Managing Users

docs.title: Viewing Task Status
docs.text:
1. Go to Task History or Task Results
  2. Filter by user, area, or status

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:

docs.title: Bulk Data Upload
docs.text: Guide for bulk uploading spatial data to GeoServer.

docs.title: File Organization
docs.text:
Organize data files in the following structure:

/media/geoserver_data/{folder_name}/
├── {dataset_name}.tif          # GeoTIFF file (for raster)
├── {dataset_name}.zip          # Shapefile ZIP (for vector)
├── {dataset_name}.sld          # Style file (optional)
└── {dataset_name}.png          # Thumbnail image

docs.title: Example Structure
docs.text:
/media/geoserver_data/Niger_LULC/
├── Niger_LULC.tif
├── Niger_LULC.sld
└── Niger_LULC.png

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
Place metadata JSON at: 

/staticData/geoserver_data.json

docs.title: JSON Format
docs.text:
[
  {
    "name": "Dataset Name",
    "description": "Dataset description",
    "data_provider": "Provider Name",
    "store_type": "geotiff",
    "keywords": "keyword1, keyword2, keyword3",
    "data_file": "geoserver_data/folder_name/dataset.tif",
    "thumbnail": "geoserver_data/folder_name/thumbnail.png",
    "sld_file": "geoserver_data/folder_name/style.sld"
  }
]

docs.title: Field Descriptions
docs.text:
• name: Unique dataset name (required)
  • description: Dataset description (optional)
  • data_provider: Data provider name (required)
  • store_type: "geotiff" or "shapefile" (required)
  • keywords: Comma-separated keywords (required)
  • data_file: Path to data file (required)
  • thumbnail: Path to thumbnail (required)
  • sld_file: Path to SLD file (optional)

docs.title: Step 1: Prepare Files
docs.text:
1. Organize data files in folders
  2. Create thumbnails for each dataset
  3. Prepare SLD files (optional)
  4. Verify file paths

docs.title: Step 2: Create Metadata JSON
docs.text:
1. Create JSON file with all datasets
  2. Verify JSON syntax
  3. Check file paths are correct
  4. Place at /staticData/geoserver_data.json

docs.title: Step 3: Trigger Upload
docs.text:
1. Log into Django Admin
  2. Navigate to Geo Data Uploads
  3. Click Trigger Bulk Upload button
  4. System processes all entries

docs.title: Step 4: Monitor Progress
docs.text:
1. Check Django logs
  2. Verify uploads in admin
  3. Test layers in GeoServer
  4. Check WMS availability

docs.title: What Happens
docs.text:
For each entry in JSON:

  1. Validation: Check if dataset exists
  2. File Check: Verify file paths exist
  3. Database: Create GeoDataUpload record
  4. GeoServer: Upload to GeoServer
  5. Publish: Publish as WMS layer
  6. Style: Apply SLD if provided

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
• Skips existing datasets
  • Logs errors for failed uploads
  • Continues with remaining entries
  • Reports final status

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Test First: Test with one dataset first
  2. Validate JSON: Check JSON syntax
  3. Verify Paths: Ensure all paths correct
  4. Check Files: Verify all files exist
  5. Unique Names: Ensure unique dataset names
  6. Backup: Backup before bulk upload
  7. Monitor: Watch logs during upload

docs.title: Upload Fails
docs.text:
• Check JSON syntax
  • Verify file paths
  • Check file permissions
  • Review error messages
  • Check GeoServer connection

docs.title: Some Datasets Fail
docs.text:
• Check individual file issues
  • Verify file formats
  • Check GeoServer logs
  • Review error messages

docs.title: Duplicate Names
docs.text:
• Ensure unique names in JSON
  • Check existing datasets
  • Remove duplicates from JSON

docs.title: File Not Found
docs.text:
• Verify file paths
  • Check file locations
  • Ensure files uploaded
  • Verify permissions

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
File Structure: 

/media/geoserver_data/
├── Dataset1/
│   ├── Dataset1.tif
│   ├── Dataset1.sld
│   └── Dataset1.png
└── Dataset2/
    ├── Dataset2.zip
    ├── Dataset2.sld
    └── Dataset2.png

JSON (/staticData/geoserver_data.json): 

[
  {
    "name": "Dataset1",
    "description": "First dataset",
    "data_provider": "Provider A",
    "store_type": "geotiff",
    "keywords": "agriculture, landcover",
    "data_file": "geoserver_data/Dataset1/Dataset1.tif",
    "thumbnail": "geoserver_data/Dataset1/Dataset1.png",
    "sld_file": "geoserver_data/Dataset1/Dataset1.sld"
  },
  {
    "name": "Dataset2",
    "description": "Second dataset",
    "data_provider": "Provider B",
    "store_type": "shapefile",
    "keywords": "boundaries, administrative",
    "data_file": "geoserver_data/Dataset2/Dataset2.zip",
    "thumbnail": "geoserver_data/Dataset2/Dataset2.png",
    "sld_file": "geoserver_data/Dataset2/Dataset2.sld"
  }
]

Return to: Admin Panel

docs.title: GeoServer Management
docs.text: Guide for managing GeoServer integration in EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Download GeoServer from geoserver.org
  2. Install and configure
  3. Start GeoServer service
  4. Access admin at http://localhost:8080/geoserver

docs.title: Workspace Configuration
docs.text:
1. Log into GeoServer admin
  2. Navigate to Workspaces
  3. Create workspace: etoolkit
  4. Set as default if needed

docs.title: User Configuration
docs.text:
Configure GeoServer user in Django settings:

GEOSERVER_USER = 'admin'
GEOSERVER_PASSWORD = 'your_password'

docs.title: Single Upload
docs.text:
1. Use Django Admin panel
  2. Go to Geo Data Uploads
  3. Add new upload
  4. System automatically:
  5. Creates store
  6. Publishes layer
  7. Configures WMS

docs.title: Bulk Upload
docs.text:
1. Organize files: 

    /media/geoserver_data/{dataset_name}/
├── {dataset_name}.tif
├── {dataset_name}.sld
└── {dataset_name}.png

  2. Create metadata JSON

  3. Place at /staticData/geoserver_data.json
  4. Trigger bulk upload from admin

• List in Django Admin

docs.title: Upload Failures

docs.title: Best Practices

1. Organize Files: Keep files organized

docs.title: API Authentication
docs.text: EO-Toolkit uses Django's session-based authentication for API access.

docs.title: Session Authentication
docs.text:
The primary authentication method uses Django sessions:

  1. Log in through web interface (/accounts/login/)
  2. Session cookie is set
  3. Subsequent API requests include session cookie
  4. Session is validated server-side

docs.title: CSRF Protection
docs.text:
POST requests require CSRF token:

  1. Get CSRF token from cookie or response header
  2. Include in request header: X-CSRFToken: <token>
  3. Or include in form data: csrfmiddlewaretoken: <token>

docs.title: Browser (JavaScript)
docs.text:
// Session cookie automatically included
fetch('/api/endpoint', {
  method: 'POST',
  headers: {
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'X-CSRFToken': getCookie('csrftoken')
  },
  credentials: 'include',
  body: JSON.stringify({...})
})

docs.title: Python (Requests)
docs.text:
import requests

session = requests.Session()

# Login first
login_response = session.post(
    'http://your-domain.com/accounts/login/',
    data={
        'username': 'your_username',
        'password': 'your_password',
        'csrfmiddlewaretoken': session.cookies.get('csrftoken')
    }
)

# Use session for API calls
response = session.post(
    'http://your-domain.com/api/endpoint',
    json={...},
    headers={'X-CSRFToken': session.cookies.get('csrftoken')}
)

docs.title: cURL
docs.text:
# Login and save cookies
curl -c cookies.txt -b cookies.txt \
  -X POST http://your-domain.com/accounts/login/ \
  -d "username=your_username&password=your_password"

# Use cookies for API calls
curl -b cookies.txt \
  -X POST http://your-domain.com/api/endpoint \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "X-CSRFToken: <token>" \
  -d '{"key": "value"}'

docs.title: Authentication Required
docs.text:
Most API endpoints require authentication. Unauthenticated requests return:

{
  "error": "Authentication required",
  "status": 401
}

docs.title: Session Expiration
docs.text:
• Sessions expire after inactivity
  • Default timeout: Configurable in Django settings
  • Re-authenticate when session expires

docs.title: Logout
docs.text:
To logout:

POST /accounts/logout/

This invalidates the session.

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
1. HTTPS: Use HTTPS in production
  2. Secure Cookies: Enable secure cookie flags
  3. CSRF Protection: Always include CSRF tokens
  4. Session Timeout: Configure appropriate timeouts
  5. Password Security: Use strong passwords

docs.title: Authentication Fails
docs.text:
• Verify credentials
  • Check session cookie is set
  • Ensure CSRF token included
  • Check session hasn't expired

docs.title: CSRF Token Errors
docs.text:
• Include CSRF token in requests
  • Get token from cookie or header
  • Ensure token matches session

docs.title: Session Expired
docs.text:
• Re-authenticate
  • Check session timeout settings
  • Implement session refresh logic

Return to: API Overview

docs.title: API Endpoints
docs.text: Complete reference for all API endpoints in EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Get Catalog Data
docs.text:
Retrieve catalog items with filtering and pagination.

Endpoint: GET /api/catalog-data/

Query Parameters: - q (string): Search query - data (string): Data type (thematic_data, training, case_studies, custom_apps) - page (integer): Page number (default: 1)

Filter Parameters (varies by data type): - gee_categories[]: GEE categories - theme[]: Themes - project_phase[]: Project phases - partner[]: Partners - category[]: Categories - source[]: Sources - language[]: Languages - publisher[]: Publishers - type[]: Types - issued_year[]: Years - keywords[]: Keywords

Response: 

{
  "results": [...],
  "page": 1,
  "total_pages": 10,
  "total_items": 300,
  "filters": {...}
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Get Added Areas List
docs.text:
Get list of areas for a country.

Endpoint: POST /api/getAddedAreasList/

Request Body: 

{
  "countryName": "Niger"
}

Response: 

[
  {
    "id": 1,
    "name": "Area Name"
  }
]

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Get Area Geometry
docs.text:
Get geometry for a specific area.

Endpoint: GET /api/getAreaGeometry/<area_id>/

Response: 

{
  "id": 1,
  "name": "Area Name",
  "country": "Niger",
  "geometry": {...}
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Add Drawn Feature
docs.text:
Add an area drawn on the map.

Endpoint: POST /api/addDrawFeature/

Request Body: 

{
  "featureName": "My Area",
  "geom": "{\"type\":\"Polygon\",\"coordinates\":[...]}",
  "countryName": "Niger"
}

Response: 

{
  "result": "Feature saved",
  "featid": 1
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Add Uploaded Layer
docs.text:
Upload a GeoJSON file as an area.

Endpoint: POST /api/addUploadedLayer/

Request Body (form-data): - featureName: Area name - countryName: Country name - file: GeoJSON file content (string)

Response: 

{
  "result": "Feature has been saved in your added areas."
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Delete Added Area
docs.text:
Delete an area.

Endpoint: GET /api/deleteAddedArea/<area_id>

Response: 

{
  "result": "Selected Area deleted"
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Get GEE Map Tile
docs.text:
Get tile URL for Google Earth Engine dataset.

Endpoint: POST /api/get-data-tile/

Request Body: 

{
  "selected_data_id": 1,
  "selected_geom": {...},
  "selectedYear": 2020
}

Response: 

{
  "tile_url": "https://...",
  "layer_name": "layer_name",
  "extent": [minLon, minLat, maxLon, maxLat],
  "legend": {...}
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Get GeoServer Layer
docs.text:
Get GeoServer layer information.

Endpoint: POST /api/get-geoserver-layer/

Request Body: 

{
  "selected_data_id": 1
}

Response: 

{
  "tile_url": "https://...",
  "layer_name": "layer_name",
  "extent": [minLon, minLat, maxLon, maxLat],
  "legend": {
    "type": "image",
    "url": "https://..."
  }
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Run Analysis
docs.text:
Execute an analysis.

Endpoint: POST /api/runAnalysis/

Request Body: 

{
  "selected_geom": {...},
  "analysis_type": "LULC"
}

Analysis Types: - LULC: Land Use Land Cover - PCP: Precipitation - ETa: Actual Evapotranspiration - ssp245: Climate Change SSP245 - ssp585: Climate Change SSP585 - GRACE: Water Storage

Response: 

{
  "analysis_type": "LULC",
  "data": [...]
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Generate Analysis Report
docs.text:
Generate a comprehensive PDF report.

Endpoint: POST /api/generateReport/

Request Body: 

{
  "areaid": 1,
  "theme": "Agriculture",
  "phase": "Planning",
  "country": "Niger"
}

Response: 

{
  "result": "Running",
  "task_id": "task-id-here"
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Get Task Status
docs.text:
Check status of an asynchronous task.

Endpoint: GET /api/get-task-status/<task_id>/

Response: 

{
  "state": "PROGRESS",
  "progress": 50,
  "total": 100,
  "status": "Processing..."
}

States: - PENDING: Task queued - PROGRESS: Task running - SUCCESS: Task completed - FAILURE: Task failed

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Delete Task History
docs.text:
Delete a saved analysis/task.

Endpoint: GET /api/deletetaskhistory/<task_id>/

Response: 

{
  "result": "Saved Analysis deleted"
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Get Recommendations Data
docs.text:
Get data recommendations based on theme, phase, and country.

Endpoint: POST /api/recommendations-data-details/

Request Body: 

{
  "theme": "Agriculture",
  "phase": "Planning",
  "country": "NER"
}

Response: 

{
  "DataRecommendations": [...],
  "TrainingMaterial": [...],
  "CaseStudies": [...],
  "SOP": [...],
  "selected_theme": "Agriculture",
  "selected_phase": "Planning",
  "selected_country": "Niger",
  "country_boundary": {...}
}

Authentication: Required

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text:
400 Bad Request: - Missing required parameters - Invalid parameter values - Validation errors

401 Unauthorized: - Not authenticated - Invalid credentials - Session expired

404 Not Found: - Resource doesn't exist - Invalid ID

500 Internal Server Error: - Server error - Processing failure

docs.title: Error Response Format
docs.text:
{
  "error": "Error message",
  "status": 400
}

See also: Authentication

docs.title: Apache Configuration
docs.text: Guide for configuring Apache web server for EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Apache installed
  • uWSGI module installed
  • SSL module installed (for HTTPS)

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install Apache
sudo apt-get install apache2

# Install uWSGI module
sudo apt install libapache2-mod-uwsgi

# Enable modules
sudo a2enmod uwsgi
sudo a2enmod ssl

docs.title: Template Location
docs.text: Template Apache configuration: etoolkit/template_apache.conf

docs.title: Copy and Modify
docs.text: sudo cp etoolkit/template_apache.conf /etc/apache2/sites-available/etoolkit.conf

docs.title: Edit Configuration
docs.text: sudo nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/etoolkit.conf

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName etoolkit.terrawatch.net
    ServerAlias www.etoolkit.terrawatch.net

    Redirect permanent / https://etoolkit.terrawatch.net/
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:443>
    ServerName etoolkit.terrawatch.net
    ServerAlias www.etoolkit.terrawatch.net

    SSLEngine on
    SSLCertificateFile /etc/letsencrypt/live/etoolkit.terrawatch.net/fullchain.pem
    SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/letsencrypt/live/etoolkit.terrawatch.net/privkey.pem

    DocumentRoot /path/to/etoolkit

    Alias /static /path/to/etoolkit/staticfiles
    Alias /media /path/to/etoolkit/media

    <Directory /path/to/etoolkit/staticfiles>
        Require all granted
    </Directory>

    <Directory /path/to/etoolkit/media>
        Require all granted
    </Directory>

    <Directory /path/to/etoolkit>
        <Files wsgi.py>
            Require all granted
        </Files>
    </Directory>

    WSGIDaemonProcess etoolkit python-home=/path/to/etoolkit/webapp/venv python-path=/path/to/etoolkit
    WSGIProcessGroup etoolkit
    WSGIScriptAlias / /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit/wsgi.py

    ErrorLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/etoolkit_error.log
    CustomLog ${APACHE_LOG_DIR}/etoolkit_access.log combined
</VirtualHost>

docs.title: Enable Site
docs.text:
# Enable site
sudo a2ensite etoolkit.conf

# Disable default site (optional)
sudo a2dissite 000-default.conf

# Test configuration
sudo apachectl configtest

# Reload Apache
sudo systemctl reload apache2

docs.title: Using Let's Encrypt
docs.text:
# Install Certbot
sudo apt install certbot python3-certbot-apache

# Obtain certificate
sudo certbot --apache -d etoolkit.terrawatch.net

# Auto-renewal (already configured)
sudo certbot renew --dry-run

docs.title: Manual SSL
docs.text:
1. Obtain SSL certificate
  2. Place certificates in secure location
  3. Update Apache configuration
  4. Restart Apache

docs.title: Collect Static Files
docs.text:
cd /path/to/etoolkit
source webapp/venv/bin/activate
python manage.py collectstatic --noinput

docs.title: Verify Static Files
docs.text:
• Check /static/ URL serves files
  • Verify file permissions
  • Check Apache can read files

docs.title: Directory Setup
docs.text:
# Create media directory
mkdir -p /path/to/etoolkit/media

# Set permissions
chmod -R 755 /path/to/etoolkit/media
chown -R www-data:www-data /path/to/etoolkit/media

docs.title: Configuration Test
docs.text: sudo apachectl configtest

docs.title: Check Apache Status
docs.text: sudo systemctl status apache2

docs.title: View Error Logs
docs.text: sudo tail -f /var/log/apache2/etoolkit_error.log

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Permission Denied: 

sudo chown -R www-data:www-data /path/to/etoolkit
sudo chmod -R 755 /path/to/etoolkit

Module Not Found: 

sudo a2enmod uwsgi
sudo systemctl restart apache2

SSL Issues: - Verify certificate paths - Check certificate validity - Verify SSL module enabled

docs.title: Enable Compression
docs.text:
LoadModule deflate_module modules/mod_deflate.so

<Location />
    SetOutputFilter DEFLATE
</Location>

docs.title: Enable Caching
docs.text:
<Location /static>
    ExpiresActive On
    ExpiresDefault "access plus 1 year"
</Location>

docs.title: Security Headers
docs.text:
Header always set X-Content-Type-Options "nosniff"
Header always set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN"
Header always set X-XSS-Protection "1; mode=block"

Next: uWSGI Setup

docs.title: Celery Configuration
docs.text: Guide for configuring Celery task queue for EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Celery handles asynchronous tasks like report generation and long-running analyses.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Redis installed and running
  • Celery installed in virtual environment
  • Database configured for results backend

docs.title: Install Redis
docs.text: sudo apt-get install redis-server

docs.title: Start Redis
docs.text:
sudo systemctl start redis
sudo systemctl enable redis

docs.title: Verify Redis
docs.text:
redis-cli ping
# Should return: PONG

docs.title: Celery Installation
docs.text:
cd /path/to/etoolkit/webapp
source venv/bin/activate
pip install celery django-celery-results redis

docs.title: Celery Configuration File
docs.text:
File: etoolkit/celery.py

from celery import Celery
import os

os.environ.setdefault('DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE', 'etoolkit.settings')

app = Celery('etoolkit')
app.config_from_object('django.conf:settings', namespace='CELERY')
app.autodiscover_tasks()

docs.title: Django Settings
docs.text:
Add to settings.py:

CELERY_BROKER_URL = 'redis://localhost:6379/0'
CELERY_RESULT_BACKEND = 'django-db'
CELERY_ACCEPT_CONTENT = ['json']
CELERY_TASK_SERIALIZER = 'json'
CELERY_RESULT_SERIALIZER = 'json'
CELERY_TIMEZONE = 'UTC'

docs.title: Create PID Directory
docs.text:
sudo mkdir /var/run/celery/
sudo chown -R etoolkit_user:etoolkit_user /var/run/celery/

docs.title: Service File
docs.text:
Create: etoolkit/etoolkit_celery.service

[Unit]
Description=Celery Service for etoolkit
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=forking
User=etoolkit_user
Group=etoolkit_user
WorkingDirectory=/path/to/etoolkit
EnvironmentFile=/path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit/celery.conf
ExecStart=/path/to/etoolkit/webapp/venv/bin/celery multi start worker1 \
    -A etoolkit \
    --pidfile=/var/run/celery/%n.pid \
    --logfile=/path/to/etoolkit/log/celery/%n.log \
    --loglevel=INFO \
    --concurrency=8 \
    --time-limit=3000
ExecStop=/path/to/etoolkit/webapp/venv/bin/celery multi stopwait worker1 \
    --pidfile=/var/run/celery/%n.pid
ExecReload=/path/to/etoolkit/webapp/venv/bin/celery multi restart worker1 \
    -A etoolkit \
    --pidfile=/var/run/celery/%n.pid \
    --logfile=/path/to/etoolkit/log/celery/%n.log \
    --loglevel=INFO \
    --concurrency=8 \
    --time-limit=3000

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

docs.title: Environment File (Optional)
docs.text:
Create: etoolkit/celery.conf

CELERY_BROKER_URL=redis://localhost:6379/0
CELERY_RESULT_BACKEND=django-db

docs.title: Create Log Directory
docs.text:
mkdir -p /path/to/etoolkit/log/celery
chown -R etoolkit_user:etoolkit_user /path/to/etoolkit/log/celery

docs.title: Link Service File
docs.text: sudo ln -s /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit/etoolkit_celery.service /etc/systemd/system/

docs.title: Enable and Start
docs.text:
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable etoolkit_celery.service
sudo systemctl start etoolkit_celery.service

docs.title: Start Service
docs.text: sudo systemctl start etoolkit_celery.service

docs.title: Stop Service
docs.text: sudo systemctl stop etoolkit_celery.service

docs.title: Restart Service
docs.text: sudo systemctl restart etoolkit_celery.service

docs.title: Check Status
docs.text: sudo systemctl status etoolkit_celery.service

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text: tail -f /path/to/etoolkit/log/celery/worker1.log

docs.title: Active Tasks
docs.text:
cd /path/to/etoolkit
source webapp/venv/bin/activate
celery -A etoolkit inspect active

docs.title: Registered Tasks
docs.text: celery -A etoolkit inspect registered

docs.title: Worker Status
docs.text: celery -A etoolkit inspect stats

docs.title: Concurrency
docs.text: --concurrency=8  # Number of worker processes

docs.title: Time Limits
docs.text:
--time-limit=3000  # Hard time limit (seconds)
--soft-time-limit=2400  # Soft time limit (seconds)

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
--loglevel=INFO  # DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR
--logfile=/path/to/log/celery/%n.log

docs.title: Service Won't Start
docs.text:
• Check Redis is running
  • Verify configuration paths
  • Check log files
  • Verify user permissions

docs.title: Tasks Not Processing
docs.text:
• Check Celery workers running
  • Verify Redis connection
  • Check task queue
  • Review error logs

docs.title: High Memory Usage
docs.text:
• Reduce concurrency
  • Adjust time limits
  • Monitor worker processes
  • Consider scaling

docs.title: Task Failures
docs.text:
• Check task logs
  • Verify task code
  • Check dependencies
  • Review error messages

docs.title: Starting Multiple Workers
docs.text:
celery multi start worker1 worker2 worker3 \
    -A etoolkit \
    --pidfile=/var/run/celery/%n.pid \
    --logfile=/path/to/etoolkit/log/celery/%n.log \
    --loglevel=INFO \
    --concurrency=4

docs.title: Stopping All Workers
docs.text:
celery multi stopwait worker1 worker2 worker3 \
    --pidfile=/var/run/celery/%n.pid

docs.title: Install Flower
docs.text: pip install flower

docs.title: Run Flower
docs.text:
celery -A etoolkit flower

Access at: http://localhost:5555

Next: SSL Configuration

docs.title: Deployment Overview
docs.text: This guide covers deploying EO-Toolkit to a production environment.

docs.title: Deployment Architecture
docs.text:
EO-Toolkit production deployment uses:

  • Apache: Web server
  • uWSGI: WSGI application server
  • Celery: Asynchronous task queue
  • Redis: Message broker for Celery
  • PostgreSQL: Database with PostGIS
  • GeoServer: Spatial data server

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Ubuntu Server (18.04+)
  • All system dependencies installed
  • Database configured
  • Application code deployed
  • SSL certificate (for HTTPS)

docs.title: Deployment Steps
docs.text:
1. Apache Setup - Configure web server
  2. uWSGI Setup - Configure application server
  3. Celery Setup - Configure task queue
  4. SSL Configuration - Enable HTTPS

docs.title: Quick Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] System dependencies installed
  • [ ] Database created and migrated
  • [ ] Static files collected
  • [ ] Media directories created
  • [ ] Apache configured
  • [ ] uWSGI configured
  • [ ] Celery configured
  • [ ] SSL certificate installed
  • [ ] Services started and enabled
  • [ ] Firewall configured
  • [ ] Monitoring set up

docs.title: Starting Services
docs.text:
sudo systemctl start etoolkit_uwsgi
sudo systemctl start etoolkit_celery
sudo systemctl start apache2

docs.title: Enabling on Boot
docs.text:
sudo systemctl enable etoolkit_uwsgi
sudo systemctl enable etoolkit_celery
sudo systemctl enable apache2

docs.title: Checking Status
docs.text:
sudo systemctl status etoolkit_uwsgi
sudo systemctl status etoolkit_celery
sudo systemctl status apache2

docs.title: Application Logs
docs.text: tail -f /path/to/etoolkit/log/etoolkit.log

docs.title: Celery Logs
docs.text: tail -f /path/to/etoolkit/log/celery/worker1.log

docs.title: Apache Logs
docs.text:
sudo tail -f /var/log/apache2/etoolkit_error.log
sudo tail -f /var/log/apache2/etoolkit_access.log

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
1. HTTPS: Always use HTTPS in production
  2. Firewall: Configure firewall rules
  3. Secrets: Keep secrets in environment variables
  4. Updates: Keep system and dependencies updated
  5. Backups: Regular database and file backups
  6. Monitoring: Set up monitoring and alerts

docs.title: Performance Optimization
docs.text:
1. Static Files: Serve via Apache/CDN
  2. Caching: Enable caching where appropriate
  3. Database: Optimize database queries
  4. Celery: Configure appropriate worker count
  5. GeoServer: Optimize GeoServer configuration

docs.title: Health Checks
docs.text:
• Application response time
  • Celery worker status
  • Database connection
  • Disk space
  • Memory usage

docs.title: Alerts
docs.text:
Set up alerts for: - Service failures - High error rates - Disk space low - High memory usage - SSL certificate expiration

Next: Apache Setup

docs.title: SSL Configuration
docs.text: Guide for configuring SSL/HTTPS for EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: SSL/TLS encryption is essential for production deployments to secure data transmission.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install certbot python3-certbot-apache

docs.title: Obtain Certificate
docs.text:
sudo certbot --apache -d etoolkit.terrawatch.net -d www.etoolkit.terrawatch.net

Follow prompts: - Enter email address - Agree to terms - Choose redirect HTTP to HTTPS

docs.title: Auto-Renewal
docs.text:
Certbot sets up auto-renewal automatically. Test renewal:

sudo certbot renew --dry-run

docs.title: Manual Renewal
docs.text: sudo certbot renew

docs.title: SSL Module
docs.text:
sudo a2enmod ssl
sudo systemctl restart apache2

docs.title: Virtual Host Configuration
docs.text:
Update Apache configuration:

<VirtualHost *:443>
    ServerName etoolkit.terrawatch.net

    SSLEngine on
    SSLCertificateFile /etc/letsencrypt/live/etoolkit.terrawatch.net/fullchain.pem
    SSLCertificateKeyFile /etc/letsencrypt/live/etoolkit.terrawatch.net/privkey.pem
    Include /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-apache.conf
    SSLCertificateChainFile /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-apache.conf

    # ... rest of configuration
</VirtualHost>

docs.title: HTTP to HTTPS Redirect
docs.text:
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName etoolkit.terrawatch.net
    Redirect permanent / https://etoolkit.terrawatch.net/
</VirtualHost>

docs.title: Obtain Certificate
docs.text:
1. Purchase from CA or use self-signed
  2. Obtain certificate files
  3. Place in secure location

docs.title: Configure Apache
docs.text:
SSLEngine on
SSLCertificateFile /path/to/certificate.crt
SSLCertificateKeyFile /path/to/private.key
SSLCertificateChainFile /path/to/chain.crt

docs.title: HSTS
docs.text: Header always set Strict-Transport-Security "max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains"

docs.title: Other Headers
docs.text:
Header always set X-Content-Type-Options "nosniff"
Header always set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN"
Header always set X-XSS-Protection "1; mode=block"
Header always set Referrer-Policy "strict-origin-when-cross-origin"

docs.title: Let's Encrypt
docs.text: Certificates expire every 90 days. Auto-renewal handles this.

docs.title: Manual Renewal
docs.text:
1. Obtain new certificate
  2. Update Apache configuration
  3. Reload Apache
  4. Verify certificate

docs.title: Certificate Not Working
docs.text:
• Verify certificate paths
  • Check certificate validity
  • Verify Apache SSL module enabled
  • Check certificate permissions

docs.title: Mixed Content Warnings
docs.text:
• Ensure all resources use HTTPS
  • Update hardcoded HTTP URLs
  • Check Django settings for HTTPS

docs.title: Certificate Expired
docs.text:
• Renew certificate
  • Update configuration
  • Reload Apache

docs.title: SSL Labs
docs.text: Test SSL configuration: https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/

docs.title: Command Line
docs.text: openssl s_client -connect etoolkit.terrawatch.net:443

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use Let's Encrypt: Free and automated
  2. Auto-Renewal: Ensure auto-renewal works
  3. Strong Ciphers: Use modern cipher suites
  4. HSTS: Enable HTTP Strict Transport Security
  5. Monitor Expiration: Set up expiration alerts
  6. Backup Certificates: Keep certificate backups

Return to: Deployment Overview

docs.title: uWSGI Configuration
docs.text: Guide for configuring uWSGI application server for EO-Toolkit.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: uWSGI serves the Django application and communicates with Apache via uwsgi protocol.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
uWSGI is typically installed via pip in the virtual environment:

cd /path/to/etoolkit/webapp
source venv/bin/activate
pip install uwsgi

docs.title: Systemd Service File
docs.text: Create service file: etoolkit/etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Example Service File
docs.text:
[Unit]
Description=uWSGI instance to serve etoolkit
After=network.target

[Service]
User=www-data
Group=www-data
WorkingDirectory=/path/to/etoolkit
Environment="PATH=/path/to/etoolkit/webapp/venv/bin"
ExecStart=/path/to/etoolkit/webapp/venv/bin/uwsgi --ini /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit/uwsgi.ini

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

docs.title: uWSGI INI File
docs.text:
Create: etoolkit/uwsgi.ini

[uwsgi]
project = etoolkit
base = /path/to/etoolkit

chdir = %(base)
module = %(project).wsgi:application
master = true
processes = 4
threads = 2

vacuum = true
die-on-term = true

socket = /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit.sock
chmod-socket = 666
uid = www-data
gid = www-data

logto = /path/to/etoolkit/log/etoolkit.log

docs.title: Create Socket Directory
docs.text:
mkdir -p /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit
chown www-data:www-data /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit

docs.title: Create Log Directory
docs.text:
mkdir -p /path/to/etoolkit/log
chown www-data:www-data /path/to/etoolkit/log

docs.title: Link Service File
docs.text: sudo ln -s /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit/etoolkit_uwsgi.service /etc/systemd/system/

docs.title: Enable and Start
docs.text:
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable etoolkit_uwsgi.service
sudo systemctl start etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Start Service
docs.text: sudo systemctl start etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Stop Service
docs.text: sudo systemctl stop etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Restart Service
docs.text: sudo systemctl restart etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Check Status
docs.text: sudo systemctl status etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: View Logs
docs.text: tail -f /path/to/etoolkit/log/etoolkit.log

docs.title: Processes and Threads
docs.text:
Adjust based on server resources:

processes = 4      # Number of worker processes
threads = 2        # Threads per process

docs.title: Socket Configuration
docs.text:
socket = /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit.sock
chmod-socket = 666

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
logto = /path/to/etoolkit/log/etoolkit.log
log-maxsize = 50000000
log-backupcount = 5

docs.title: Service Won't Start
docs.text:
• Check configuration file paths
  • Verify user permissions
  • Check log file for errors
  • Verify virtual environment path

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text:
sudo chown -R www-data:www-data /path/to/etoolkit
sudo chmod -R 755 /path/to/etoolkit

docs.title: Socket Issues
docs.text:
• Check socket file permissions
  • Verify Apache can access socket
  • Check socket file exists
  • Restart both uWSGI and Apache

docs.title: High Memory Usage
docs.text:
• Reduce number of processes
  • Reduce threads per process
  • Monitor memory usage
  • Consider server upgrade

docs.title: Worker Configuration
docs.text:
# For CPU-bound tasks
processes = (2 * CPU cores) + 1
threads = 2

# For I/O-bound tasks
processes = CPU cores
threads = 4

docs.title: Memory Limits
docs.text:
limit-as = 512
reload-on-as = 400

docs.title: Harakiri (Request Timeout)
docs.text:
harakiri = 60
harakiri-verbose = true

docs.title: Graceful Reload
docs.text: sudo systemctl reload etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Full Restart
docs.text: sudo systemctl restart etoolkit_uwsgi.service

docs.title: Process Status
docs.text: ps aux | grep uwsgi

docs.title: Socket Status
docs.text: ls -l /path/to/etoolkit/etoolkit.sock

docs.title: Connection Count
docs.text:
Monitor Apache access logs for connection patterns.

Next: Celery Setup

docs.title: Analysis Types
docs.text: EO-Toolkit supports various analysis types for Earth Observation data. This document details each analysis type.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Analyzes land cover types and their distribution within a selected area.

docs.title: Data Source
docs.text:
• ESA WorldCover
  • MODIS Land Cover
  • Dynamic World

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• Pie Chart: Distribution of land cover classes
  • Statistics: Area (hectares) per class
  • Percentages: Percentage breakdown

docs.title: Land Cover Classes
docs.text:
Common classes include:

  • Cropland
  • Grassland
  • Tree Cover
  • Shrubland
  • Built-up
  • Permanent Water Bodies
  • Herbaceous Wetland
  • Bare/Sparse Vegetation

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Agricultural planning
  • Forest monitoring
  • Urban development assessment
  • Environmental impact studies
  • Land use change detection

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• Area: Required (polygon geometry)
  • Year: Optional (for time-specific analysis)

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
[
  {
    "value": 40,
    "label": "Cropland",
    "area_ha": 669.97,
    "percentage": 46.81
  },
  {
    "value": 30,
    "label": "Grassland",
    "area_ha": 530.2,
    "percentage": 37.05
  }
]

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Analyzes precipitation patterns using CHIRPS data.

docs.title: Data Source
docs.text: CHIRPS (Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data)

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• Time Series: Annual/monthly precipitation
  • Statistics: Mean, min, max values
  • Trends: Precipitation trends over time

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Drought monitoring
  • Water resource planning
  • Agricultural planning
  • Climate studies
  • Flood risk assessment

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• Area: Required
  • Start Year: Beginning of analysis period
  • End Year: End of analysis period
  • Aggregation: Annual, Monthly, etc.

docs.title: Temporal Coverage
docs.text:
• Typically: 1981 to present
  • Daily, monthly, annual aggregations
  • Near real-time updates

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Analyzes actual evapotranspiration rates using WaPOR data.

docs.title: Data Source
docs.text: WaPOR (Water Productivity Open-access Portal)

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• Time Series: ETa values over time
  • Statistics: Mean, seasonal patterns
  • Trends: ETa trends

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Irrigation planning
  • Water management
  • Agricultural productivity assessment
  • Drought monitoring
  • Water balance studies

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• Area: Required
  • Start Year: Beginning of analysis period
  • End Year: End of analysis period
  • Aggregation: Annual, Monthly, etc.

docs.title: Temporal Coverage
docs.text:
• Typically: 2009 to present
  • 10-day, monthly, annual aggregations
  • 250m resolution

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Projects future climate scenarios using climate models.

docs.title: SSP245 (Moderate Emissions)
docs.text:
• Moderate mitigation efforts
  • Intermediate warming pathway
  • Representative of current policies

docs.title: SSP585 (High Emissions)
docs.text:
• High emissions scenario
  • Limited mitigation
  • High warming pathway

docs.title: Data Source
docs.text:
• NEX-GDDP
  • CMIP6 models
  • NASA Earth Exchange

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• Temperature Projections: Future temperature trends
  • Precipitation Projections: Future precipitation patterns
  • Trend Analysis: Long-term trends
  • Comparison: Scenario comparison

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Climate adaptation planning
  • Risk assessment
  • Long-term planning
  • Policy development
  • Infrastructure planning

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• Area: Required
  • Scenario: SSP245 or SSP585
  • Projection Period: Future years

docs.title: Temporal Coverage
docs.text:
• Historical: 1950-2014
  • Projections: 2015-2100
  • Monthly and annual data

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Analyzes terrestrial water storage changes using GRACE data.

docs.title: Data Source
docs.text:
• GRACE (2002-2017)
  • GRACE-FO (2018-present)

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• Time Series: Water storage anomalies
  • Trends: Long-term trends
  • Seasonal Patterns: Seasonal variations
  • Anomalies: Deviations from mean

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Groundwater monitoring
  • Water resource assessment
  • Drought analysis
  • Hydrological studies
  • Water balance analysis

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• Area: Required
  • Temporal Range: Available data period

docs.title: Temporal Coverage
docs.text:
• GRACE: 2002-2017
  • GRACE-FO: 2018-present
  • Monthly resolution
  • ~300km spatial resolution

docs.title: General Process
docs.text:
1. Select Area: Choose area of interest
  2. Choose Analysis: Select analysis type
  3. Configure Parameters: Set dates, options
  4. Run Analysis: Execute analysis
  5. View Results: Charts and visualizations
  6. Export/Report: Include in reports

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Small Areas (< 100 km²): Usually < 1 minute
  • Medium Areas (100-1000 km²): 1-5 minutes
  • Large Areas (> 1000 km²): 5-15+ minutes

docs.title: Factors Affecting Speed
docs.text:
• Area size
  • Temporal range
  • Dataset complexity
  • Server load
  • Network speed

docs.title: Multi-Analysis Approach
docs.text:
Run multiple analyses for comprehensive insights:

  1. LULC: Understand land cover
  2. Precipitation: Assess water availability
  3. ETa: Evaluate water use
  4. Climate: Project future conditions
  5. Water Storage: Monitor groundwater

docs.title: Integrated Reports
docs.text:
Combine results in comprehensive reports:

  • Executive summary
  • Multiple analysis results
  • Cross-analysis insights
  • Recommendations
  • Visualizations

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Start Simple: Begin with basic analyses
  2. Verify Area: Ensure correct area selection
  3. Check Coverage: Verify data availability
  4. Review Results: Always review for reasonableness
  5. Document Parameters: Note analysis settings
  6. Compare Periods: Compare different time periods
  7. Validate: Cross-check with known values

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• No Data: Area outside coverage
  • Slow Processing: Large area or complex analysis
  • Errors: Invalid parameters or geometry
  • Timeout: Long-running operations

docs.title: Solutions
docs.text:
• Verify area within data coverage
  • Reduce area size or temporal range
  • Check parameter validity
  • Retry after delay
  • Contact support if persistent

Next: Custom Apps

docs.title: Custom Apps Feature
docs.text: The Custom Apps feature allows administrators to add external applications and tools to the EO-Toolkit catalog.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Custom Apps enable:

  • Integration of external tools
  • Access to partner applications
  • Extended functionality
  • Resource sharing

docs.title: Through Admin Panel
docs.text:
1. Log in as administrator
  2. Navigate to Django Admin
  3. Go to Custom Apps
  4. Click Add Custom App
  5. Fill in form:
  6. Name: App name (unique)
  7. Description: App description
  8. Link: URL to application
  9. Thumbnail: Preview image
  10. Keywords: Comma-separated keywords
  11. Click Save

docs.title: Required Fields
docs.text:
• Name: Unique identifier
  • Description: What the app does
  • Link: Valid URL
  • Thumbnail: Image file
  • Keywords: For search/filtering

docs.title: Viewing Apps
docs.text:
• Browse in Custom Apps catalog
  • Search by keywords
  • Filter by keywords
  • View app details

docs.title: Updating Apps
docs.text:
• Edit metadata in admin
  • Update links
  • Replace thumbnails
  • Modify keywords

docs.title: Deleting Apps
docs.text:
• Delete from admin panel
  • Thumbnail automatically removed
  • App removed from catalog

docs.title: Display
docs.text:
Apps appear in catalog with:

  • Thumbnail image
  • App name
  • Description
  • Keywords
  • Direct link

docs.title: Access
docs.text:
Users can:

  • Browse apps
  • Search apps
  • Filter by keywords
  • Access external apps
  • View app details

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Descriptive Names: Use clear, descriptive names
  2. Complete Descriptions: Provide detailed descriptions
  3. Relevant Keywords: Use appropriate keywords
  4. Quality Thumbnails: Use clear preview images
  5. Valid Links: Ensure links are working
  6. Regular Updates: Keep information current

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Partner tool integration
  • External resource access
  • Extended functionality
  • Educational resources
  • Complementary tools

This completes the Features documentation. Continue to: - API Reference - Administration Guide

docs.title: Data Catalog Feature
docs.text: The Data Catalog is a central feature providing access to Earth Observation datasets, training materials, case studies, and custom applications.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Data Catalog serves as a comprehensive repository for:

  • Earth Observation datasets
  • Educational resources
  • Real-world examples
  • External applications
  • Partner information

docs.title: Thematic Data
docs.text:
Earth Observation datasets from multiple sources:

  • Google Earth Engine Datasets: GEE catalog integration
  • GeoServer Layers: Uploaded spatial data
  • Metadata: Rich dataset information
  • Visualization: Map previews and thumbnails

Features: - Search and filter capabilities - Detailed metadata - Map visualization - Download options (where available)

docs.title: Training Materials
docs.text:
Educational resources and tutorials:

  • Categories: Organized by topic
  • Sources: Various providers
  • Languages: Multiple language support
  • Formats: Documents, videos, guides

Use Cases: - Learning EO concepts - Tool tutorials - Best practices - Technical guides

docs.title: Case Studies
docs.text:
Real-world application examples:

  • Publishers: Organizations and institutions
  • Types: Various study types
  • Years: Publication dates
  • Topics: Subject areas

Benefits: - Learn from examples - Understand applications - Get inspiration - See best practices

docs.title: Custom Apps
docs.text:
External applications and tools:

  • Keywords: Topic-based organization
  • Links: Direct access
  • Descriptions: App information
  • Thumbnails: Visual previews

docs.title: Search Functionality
docs.text:
• Full-text Search: Across titles and descriptions
  • Keyword Matching: Intelligent keyword search
  • Instant Results: Real-time filtering

docs.title: Filtering System
docs.text:
Thematic Data Filters: - GEE Categories - Theme - Project Phase - Partner/Provider

Training Material Filters: - Category - Source - Language

Case Study Filters: - Publisher - Type - Issued Year

Custom App Filters: - Keywords

docs.title: Pagination
docs.text:
• 30 items per page
  • Easy navigation
  • Page indicators
  • Total count display

docs.title: Information Displayed
docs.text:
• Title: Dataset name
  • Description: Detailed information
  • Provider: Data source
  • Keywords: Relevant tags
  • Spatial Extent: Coverage area
  • Temporal Coverage: Time period
  • Thumbnail: Visual preview

docs.title: Actions Available
docs.text:
• View on Map: Visualize dataset
  • View Details: Full information
  • Download: If available
  • Share: Share dataset link

docs.title: Uploaded Datasets
docs.text:
Administrators can upload:

  • Raster Data: GeoTIFF files
  • Vector Data: Shapefiles
  • Styles: SLD styling files
  • Thumbnails: Preview images

docs.title: Layer Management
docs.text:
• Automatic GeoServer publishing
  • WMS service generation
  • Style application
  • Metadata management

docs.title: Contextual Recommendations
docs.text: Based on: - Selected theme - Project phase - Country selection

docs.title: Recommendation Types
docs.text:
• Datasets: Relevant EO data
  • Training: Educational materials
  • Case Studies: Similar projects
  • SOPs: Standard procedures

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use Filters: Narrow down efficiently
  2. Read Metadata: Understand data before use
  3. Check Coverage: Verify spatial/temporal coverage
  4. Explore Related: Discover connected resources
  5. Save Favorites: Bookmark useful items

docs.title: Data Sources
docs.text:
• Google Earth Engine API
  • GeoServer WMS/WFS
  • Static JSON catalogs
  • Database queries

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
• Optimized queries
  • Caching where applicable
  • Pagination for large results

Next: GeoServer Integration

docs.title: GeoServer Integration
docs.text: EO-Toolkit integrates with GeoServer to manage and serve spatial data layers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
GeoServer integration enables:

  • Upload and publish spatial data
  • Serve data via WMS/WFS
  • Style layers with SLD files
  • Manage raster and vector data
  • Integrate with map viewers

docs.title: Raster Data
docs.text:
• Format: GeoTIFF (.tif, .tiff)
  • Projection: EPSG:4326 (WGS84) or auto-detected
  • Bands: Single or multi-band
  • Compression: Various compression formats supported

docs.title: Vector Data
docs.text:
• Format: Shapefile (ZIP archive)
  • Geometry Types: Polygon, MultiPolygon
  • Attributes: Preserved in GeoServer
  • Projection: EPSG:4326 (WGS84)

docs.title: Through Admin Panel
docs.text:
1. Log in as administrator
  2. Navigate to Django Admin
  3. Go to Geo Data Uploads
  4. Click Add Geo Data Upload
  5. Fill in form:
  6. Name (unique)
  7. Description
  8. Data Provider
  9. Data File (GeoTIFF or Shapefile ZIP)
  10. Thumbnail Image
  11. Store Type (GeoTIFF or Shapefile)
  12. Keywords (comma-separated)
  13. SLD File (optional)
  14. Click Save

docs.title: Automatic Processing
docs.text:
Upon upload:

  1. File is validated
  2. Data is copied to media directory
  3. GeoServer store is created
  4. Layer is published
  5. WMS service is configured
  6. Metadata is stored in database

docs.title: Workspace
docs.text:
• Default workspace: etoolkit
  • Configurable in settings
  • All layers published to workspace

docs.title: Layer Naming
docs.text:
• Uses dataset name
  • Sanitized for GeoServer
  • Must be unique within workspace

docs.title: Styling
docs.text:
• SLD Files: Upload custom styles
  • Default Styles: Auto-applied if no SLD
  • Legend: Generated automatically

docs.title: WMS Service
docs.text:
Layers are accessible via WMS:

{GEOSERVER_WMS_URL}/{workspace}/wms?service=WMS&version=1.1.1&request=GetMap&layers={workspace}:{layer_name}&styles=&bbox={bbox}&width=256&height=256&srs=EPSG:3857&format=image/png

docs.title: In Application
docs.text:
• Layers appear in Data Catalog
  • Can be viewed on map
  • Extent information available
  • Legend URLs provided

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text:
1. Organize data files: 

    /media/geoserver_data/{folder_name}/
├── {dataset_name}.tif
├── {dataset_name}.sld
└── {dataset_name}.png

  2. Create metadata JSON: 

    [
  {
    "name": "Dataset Name",
    "description": "Description",
    "data_provider": "Provider",
    "store_type": "geotiff",
    "keywords": "keyword1, keyword2"
  }
]

  3. Place JSON at: /staticData/geoserver_data.json

docs.title: Triggering Bulk Upload
docs.text:
1. Go to Django Admin
  2. Navigate to Geo Data Uploads
  3. Click Trigger Bulk Upload button
  4. System processes all entries
  5. Check logs for status

docs.title: Viewing Layers
docs.text:
• List all layers in admin
  • View layer details
  • Check GeoServer status
  • Verify WMS availability

docs.title: Updating Layers
docs.text:
• Edit metadata in admin
  • Replace data file (re-upload)
  • Update styles (upload new SLD)
  • Modify keywords/description

docs.title: Deleting Layers
docs.text:
• Delete from admin panel
  • Automatic cleanup:
  • GeoServer layer removed
  • Store deleted
  • Files removed from disk

docs.title: Upload Fails
docs.text: Solutions: - Check file format - Verify file permissions - Check GeoServer connection - Review server logs - Verify workspace exists

docs.title: Layer Not Appearing
docs.text: Solutions: - Check GeoServer logs - Verify layer published - Test WMS URL directly - Check workspace name - Verify permissions

docs.title: Style Issues
docs.text: Solutions: - Validate SLD syntax - Check style compatibility - Verify style name matches - Test in GeoServer admin

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text: Solutions: - Optimize raster files - Use appropriate resolution - Consider tiling - Check GeoServer configuration

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. File Organization: Keep files organized
  2. Naming: Use descriptive, unique names
  3. Metadata: Provide complete metadata
  4. Styles: Create appropriate SLD files
  5. Thumbnails: Include preview images
  6. Keywords: Use relevant keywords
  7. Testing: Test layers after upload

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
Configure in settings.py:

GEOSERVER_URL = 'http://localhost:8080/geoserver'
GEOSERVER_WMS_URL = 'http://localhost:8080/geoserver'
GEOSERVER_USER = 'admin'
GEOSERVER_PASSWORD = 'geoserver'
GEOSERVER_WORKSPACE = 'etoolkit'

docs.title: GeoServer Setup
docs.text:
1. Install GeoServer
  2. Create workspace
  3. Configure credentials
  4. Set up data directory
  5. Test connection

Next: Google Earth Engine Integration

docs.title: Google Earth Engine Integration
docs.text: EO-Toolkit leverages Google Earth Engine (GEE) for powerful geospatial analysis and data access.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Google Earth Engine integration provides:

  • Access to vast EO data catalog
  • Cloud-based processing
  • Time series analysis
  • Advanced analytics
  • High-performance computing

docs.title: Service Account Setup
docs.text:
1. Create Google Cloud Project
  2. Enable Earth Engine API
  3. Create service account
  4. Download service account key JSON
  5. Configure in environment:
EE_KEY='{"type":"service_account",...}'

docs.title: Initialization
docs.text:
GEE is initialized automatically when needed:

import ee
# Service account credentials loaded from environment
ee.Initialize(credentials)

docs.title: Land Use Land Cover
docs.text:
• ESA WorldCover: Global land cover
  • MODIS Land Cover: MODIS-based classification
  • Dynamic World: Near real-time land cover

docs.title: Precipitation
docs.text:
• CHIRPS: Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation
  • GPM: Global Precipitation Measurement
  • PERSIANN: Precipitation Estimation from Remotely Sensed Information

docs.title: Evapotranspiration
docs.text:
• WaPOR: Water Productivity Open-access Portal
  • MODIS ET: MODIS Evapotranspiration
  • SSEBop: Operational Simplified Surface Energy Balance

docs.title: Climate Data
docs.text:
• ERA5: ECMWF Reanalysis
  • NEX-GDDP: NASA Earth Exchange Global Daily Downscaled Projections
  • CMIP6: Climate Model Intercomparison Project

docs.title: Water Storage
docs.text:
• GRACE: Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment
  • GRACE-FO: GRACE Follow-On

docs.title: Tile Layer Generation
docs.text:
Generate map tile URLs for visualization:

tile_url, layer_name, extent, legend = get_gee_map_tileLayer(
    dataset_id, geometry
)

docs.title: Time Series Analysis
docs.text:
Extract time series data:

timeseries = get_gee_time_series_from_ImageCollection(
    selected_geom=geometry,
    ImageCollection=collection,
    band="precipitation",
    scale=5000
)

docs.title: Image Collection Listing
docs.text:
List available images in collection:

images = list_collection_images(
    collection_id, start_date, end_date
)

docs.title: CHIRPS Precipitation
docs.text:
# Annual collection
collection = get_chirps_annual_precip_collection(
    start_year, end_year, aggregation, geometry
)

# Time series
timeseries = get_gee_time_series_from_ImageCollection(
    selected_geom=geometry,
    ImageCollection=collection,
    band="PCP",
    scale=5000
)

docs.title: WaPOR ETa
docs.text:
# Collection
collection = get_wapor_eta_collection(
    start_year, end_year, aggregation, geometry
)

# Time series
timeseries = get_gee_time_series_from_ImageCollection(
    selected_geom=geometry,
    ImageCollection=collection,
    band="ETa",
    scale=300
)

docs.title: LULC Analysis
docs.text:
# Pie chart data
lulc_data = get_lulc_pieChart(selected_geom=geometry)

docs.title: Climate Change Analysis
docs.text:
# SSP245 scenario
result = climate_change_analysis(geometry, scenario='ssp245')

# SSP585 scenario
result = climate_change_analysis(geometry, scenario='ssp585')

docs.title: Water Storage Analysis
docs.text:
# GRACE analysis
timeseries = water_storage_analysis(selected_geom=geometry)

docs.title: Geometry Handling
docs.text:
• Accepts GeoJSON geometries
  • Converts to EE Geometry objects
  • Handles polygons and multipolygons
  • Validates geometry

docs.title: Scale and Resolution
docs.text:
• Appropriate scale for each dataset
  • Balances accuracy and performance
  • Configurable per analysis

docs.title: Temporal Filtering
docs.text:
• Date range selection
  • Image collection filtering
  • Time series aggregation

docs.title: Processing Time
docs.text:
• Depends on area size
  • Dataset complexity
  • Temporal range
  • GEE server load

docs.title: Optimization Tips
docs.text:
• Use appropriate scales
  • Limit temporal ranges
  • Reduce area size when possible
  • Cache results when applicable

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
• Quota Exceeded: GEE quota limits
  • Invalid Geometry: Geometry validation errors
  • Dataset Not Found: Invalid dataset ID
  • Timeout: Long-running operations

docs.title: Solutions
docs.text:
• Check GEE quotas
  • Validate geometries
  • Verify dataset IDs
  • Use smaller areas/dates
  • Retry failed operations

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Validate Geometries: Ensure valid GeoJSON
  2. Appropriate Scales: Use dataset-appropriate scales
  3. Limit Temporal Range: Don't request excessive date ranges
  4. Error Handling: Implement proper error handling
  5. Caching: Cache results when possible
  6. Monitoring: Monitor GEE quota usage

docs.title: JSON Configuration
docs.text:
Datasets are configured in gee_datasets.json:

{
  "DataID": 1,
  "title": "Dataset Name",
  "description": "Description",
  "gee_categories": ["category1"],
  "theme": "Agriculture",
  "project_phase": "Planning",
  "partner": "Provider",
  "spatial_extent": [minLon, minLat, maxLon, maxLat],
  "temporal_coverage": "2000-2024",
  "gee_collection": "collection/path"
}

docs.title: Adding New Datasets
docs.text:
1. Add entry to gee_datasets.json
  2. Configure collection path
  3. Set appropriate metadata
  4. Test dataset access
  5. Update documentation

docs.title: Credentials Management
docs.text:
• Store service account key securely
  • Use environment variables
  • Never commit keys to repository
  • Rotate keys regularly

docs.title: Access Control
docs.text:
• GEE quotas apply
  • Monitor usage
  • Implement rate limiting
  • Handle errors gracefully

Next: Analysis Types

docs.title: Configuration Guide
docs.text: This guide covers the essential configuration steps for EO-Toolkit after installation.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
EO-Toolkit uses environment variables for sensitive configuration. Create a .env file in the project root:

cd /path/to/etoolkit
nano .env

docs.title: Required Environment Variables
docs.text:
# Django Settings
DJANGO_ENV=development
SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key-here
BASE_URL=http://localhost:8000

# Database Configuration
DB_NAME=etoolkit
DB_USER=etoolkit
DB_PASSWORD=etoolkit123
DB_HOST=localhost
DB_PORT=5432

# GeoServer Configuration
GEOSERVER_URL=http://localhost:8080/geoserver
GEOSERVER_WMS_URL=http://localhost:8080/geoserver
GEOSERVER_USER=admin
GEOSERVER_PASSWORD=geoserver
GEOSERVER_WORKSPACE=etoolkit

# Email Configuration (for OTP and notifications)
EMAIL_HOST=smtp.gmail.com
EMAIL_PORT=587
EMAIL_HOST_USER=your-email@gmail.com
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD=your-app-password
EMAIL_USE_TLS=True

# Google Earth Engine (if using)
EE_KEY={"type":"service_account",...}

Security

Never commit the .env file to version control. It contains sensitive information.

docs.title: Database Settings
docs.text:
Edit etoolkit/settings.py:

DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.contrib.gis.db.backends.postgis',
        'NAME': config('DB_NAME', default='etoolkit'),
        'USER': config('DB_USER', default='etoolkit'),
        'PASSWORD': config('DB_PASSWORD'),
        'HOST': config('DB_HOST', default='localhost'),
        'PORT': config('DB_PORT', default='5432'),
    }
}

docs.title: Static and Media Files
docs.text:
STATIC_URL = '/static/'
STATIC_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'staticfiles')

MEDIA_URL = '/media/'
MEDIA_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'media')

docs.title: Allowed Hosts
docs.text:
For production, update ALLOWED_HOSTS:

ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['yourdomain.com', 'www.yourdomain.com']

docs.title: CSRF Trusted Origins
docs.text: CSRF_TRUSTED_ORIGINS = ['https://yourdomain.com']

docs.title: Install GeoServer
docs.text:
1. Download GeoServer from geoserver.org
  2. Extract and configure
  3. Start GeoServer service

docs.title: Create Workspace
docs.text:
1. Log into GeoServer admin panel (usually http://localhost:8080/geoserver)
  2. Navigate to Workspaces → Add new workspace
  3. Create workspace named etoolkit (or your configured workspace name)

docs.title: Configure Data Directory
docs.text:
Ensure GeoServer has access to your data directory:

# Create data directory
mkdir -p /path/to/etoolkit/media/geoserver_data

# Set permissions
chmod -R 755 /path/to/etoolkit/media/geoserver_data

docs.title: Redis Configuration
docs.text:
Redis is used for Celery task queue. Ensure Redis is running:

# Check Redis status
sudo systemctl status redis

# Start Redis if not running
sudo systemctl start redis

# Enable Redis on boot
sudo systemctl enable redis

docs.title: Celery Configuration
docs.text:
Celery configuration is in etoolkit/celery.py. Key settings:

broker_url = 'redis://localhost:6379/0'
result_backend = 'django-db'

docs.title: Email Configuration
docs.text:
For email verification and notifications:

EMAIL_BACKEND = 'django.core.mail.backends.smtp.EmailBackend'
EMAIL_HOST = config('EMAIL_HOST')
EMAIL_PORT = config('EMAIL_PORT', cast=int)
EMAIL_USE_TLS = config('EMAIL_USE_TLS', cast=bool, default=True)
EMAIL_HOST_USER = config('EMAIL_HOST_USER')
EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD = config('EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD')
DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL = config('EMAIL_HOST_USER')

Gmail Setup

For Gmail, you'll need to: 1. Enable 2-factor authentication 2. Generate an app-specific password 3. Use the app password in EMAIL_HOST_PASSWORD

docs.title: Google Earth Engine Setup
docs.text:
If using Google Earth Engine features:

  1. Create a Google Cloud Project
  2. Enable Earth Engine API
  3. Create a service account
  4. Download the service account key JSON
  5. Set EE_KEY environment variable with the JSON content

docs.title: Logging Configuration
docs.text:
Configure logging in settings.py:

LOGGING = {
    'version': 1,
    'disable_existing_loggers': False,
    'handlers': {
        'file': {
            'level': 'INFO',
            'class': 'logging.FileHandler',
            'filename': os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'log', 'etoolkit.log'),
        },
    },
    'loggers': {
        'django': {
            'handlers': ['file'],
            'level': 'INFO',
            'propagate': True,
        },
    },
}

docs.title: Verify Configuration
docs.text:
Test your configuration:

# Check Django settings
python manage.py check

# Test database connection
python manage.py dbshell

# Test Celery connection
celery -A etoolkit inspect active

# Test GeoServer connection
curl -u admin:geoserver http://localhost:8080/geoserver/rest/workspaces.json

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:

  • Deployment Guide - Configure for production

docs.title: First Steps
docs.text: Welcome to EO-Toolkit! This guide will help you get started with using the application.

docs.title: Accessing the Application
docs.text:
1. Open your web browser
  2. Navigate to your EO-Toolkit URL:
  3. Development: http://localhost:8000
  4. Production: https://etoolkit.terrawatch.net

docs.title: Step 1: Register
docs.text:
1. Click on Sign Up or navigate to /accounts/register/
  2. Fill in the registration form:
  3. Username
  4. Email address
  5. Password (choose a strong password)
  6. Confirm password
  7. Click Register

docs.title: Step 2: Email Verification
docs.text:
After registration, you'll be redirected to the email verification page:

  1. Click Send OTP to receive a verification code
  2. Check your email for the 6-digit OTP
  3. Enter the OTP in the verification form
  4. Click Verify

OTP Expiration

OTP codes expire after a certain time. If expired, click Send OTP again to receive a new code.

docs.title: Step 3: Login
docs.text:
Once verified:

  1. Navigate to the login page (/accounts/login/)
  2. Enter your username and password
  3. Click Sign In

docs.title: Exploring the Dashboard
docs.text:
After logging in, you'll see the main dashboard with:

  • Navigation Menu: Access different sections
  • Data Catalog: Browse available datasets
  • Search: Find data and resources
  • User Menu: Access your profile and settings

docs.title: Step 1: Create an Area
docs.text:
Before running an analysis, you need to define an area of interest:

  1. Navigate to the Data Map or Search page
  2. Use the drawing tools to:
  3. Draw a polygon: Click on the map to create vertices
  4. Upload a GeoJSON: Upload a pre-defined area file
  5. Give your area a name and select the country
  6. Save the area

docs.title: Step 2: Browse Data Catalog
docs.text:
1. Go to Data Catalog from the navigation menu
  2. Browse available datasets:
  3. Thematic Data (GEE datasets)
  4. GeoServer layers
  5. Training materials
  6. Case studies
  7. Use filters to narrow down:
  8. By category
  9. By theme
  10. By partner/provider
  11. By keywords

docs.title: Step 3: View Data on Map
docs.text:
1. Click on a dataset from the catalog
  2. The dataset details page will open
  3. Click View on Map to visualize the data
  4. The layer will be added to the map viewer

docs.title: Step 4: Run an Analysis
docs.text:
1. Select your area from the area selector
  2. Choose an analysis type:
  3. LULC: Land Use Land Cover analysis
  4. PCP: Precipitation analysis
  5. ETa: Actual Evapotranspiration
  6. Climate Change: SSP245 or SSP585 scenarios
  7. GRACE: Water storage analysis
  8. Click Run Analysis
  9. Wait for the analysis to complete
  10. View results in charts and visualizations

docs.title: Step 5: Generate a Report
docs.text:
1. After running analyses, go to your saved areas
  2. Select an area with completed analyses
  3. Click Generate Report
  4. Fill in:
  5. Theme (e.g., Agriculture, Water, Climate)
  6. Project Phase
  7. Country
  8. The report will be generated asynchronously
  9. Check the task status and download when ready

docs.title: Data Catalog
docs.text:
• Thematic Data: Earth Observation datasets from Google Earth Engine
  • Training Materials: Educational resources and tutorials
  • Case Studies: Real-world application examples

docs.text:

  • Upload Areas: Upload GeoJSON files
  • Manage Areas: View, edit, and delete saved areas

docs.title: Analysis Tools
docs.text:

  • Time Series: View temporal data trends
  • Charts: Interactive visualizations
  • Export: Download analysis results

1. Start Small: Begin with a small area to understand the workflow
  2. Explore Data: Browse the catalog to see what data is available
  3. Read Descriptions: Dataset descriptions provide important information
  4. Check Examples: Review case studies for inspiration

  • Contact: Use the Contact Us form for support
